div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of newspaper clipping, [La Discusion], [November 21, 1900] (See Spanish original)
div1.p:
Yellow fever transmitted to Spanish immigrants
by mosquitos!

A rumor of an act so horrific, repugnant
and monstrous has come to us, that
hesitating to believe in its existence,
almost daring to deny it, we do not
hesitate to record it -only by way of
rumor-in our columns, because in that
way the popular version will arrive
directly and quickly to the authorities,
and they; if as we hope the deed turns
out false, will dispel alarm and if- what
we do not believe- it were true, will
impose upon its authors an exemplary
punishment, whose importance is at the
height of the monstrous magnitud of the
crime.

As is known, for some time now, the
current of Spanish immigration to this
island has increased. The large portion
of those immigrants, as is natural, aren't
immune to yellow fever.

Those who stay a short time in
Triscornia are offered work in an
American camp in los Quemados,
promising them a peso daily, and are
carried in groups "partidas" of 30 or 40
men.

And here enters the horrible part of the
story.

At night, when the immigrants have
finished their work, they are enclosed in
some special rooms and in then a large
number of mosquitos that have bitten
individuals with yellow fever are
released. The object of it, is to study
practically if the contagion originates or
can originate through the innoculation of
those bites. If the worker becomes sick
and dies, the experiment has
demonstrated the fact; in the opposite
case, it has completely cleared up that
fear.

Such is, referred to as briefly as possible,
the case.

If, unfortunately, its existence is proven,
it would be the most monstrous case of
humanitarian... savagry that we've ever
witnessed. To do experiments in ánima
vili on the body of people, and to people,
though poor, honest, hard working and
good, who come to a country in search
of wealth, well-being and work,
believing to have found all of the
guarantees of civilized life and of free
peoples, would be unheard of, and would
demand (as La Discusión demands it in
the name of Cuban opinion, for that very
reason that it deals with a modest, hard
working dignified element of the
Spanish colony) such a punishment, that
its exemplary nature erase forever all
fear that the vile crime- for it has no
other name - could repeat itself.

In any case, we believe it useless to
repeat that, in our judgment, the act is
not possible; but in case it were true, our
personal and juournalistic integrity
makes us declare, in which refers to the
intervention of the higher authorities in
the case, and for the very reason that our
opposition to the misguided acts of
General Wood has been clear and
frank- that we are persuaded that
neither complicity nor tolerance, but also
not even knowledge of that sad point
could the military governor, General
Wood or Col. Scott, who worthily
substitutes in his absence, have.
